Although many Americans felt that the current military effort was not going well in 2015, as evidenced by the consistently negative assessments of the campaign [1], there was still optimism about the ultimate outcome. 

![Public opinion on the likelihood of the U.S. and its allies succeeding in their campaign against Islamic militants.](image4)

This optimism can be seen in the increased belief that the U.S. and its allies will eventually succeed in the military campaign against ISIS [2, 4, 9]. In December 2015, two-thirds of Americans believed that the U.S. and its allies would probably or definitely succeed [9]. This represents an 11-point increase from July 2015 [9].

Despite the recent attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, there was no significant shift in public opinion on the likelihood of success [8].  The public remained largely divided on whether to send U.S. ground troops to fight, with 47% in favor and 47% opposed [5]. 

In conclusion, more people still believed that the U.S. and its allies would succeed in the ISIS fight in the end in 2015.

A large majority of Americans are familiar with and consider it realistic that automation may impact a wide range of human jobs.  [2] 85% of the public has heard about automation impacting jobs. Additionally, 77% believe this is at least somewhat realistic.  [2] 

People’s opinions on the effects of automation are divided, as illustrated below:  
![Opinions on the effects of automation are divided](image1) 

For instance, 76% believe that inequality between the wealthy and poor will increase as a result of this.  [1, 6]  However, 75% also think that the economy will generate many new, better-paying positions for humans. [1, 6] 
In terms of specific solutions, a sizable majority of Americans, regardless of political affiliation, believe that machines should only be used for dangerous or unhealthy employment. [6] 

![A sizable majority of Americans believe machines should be limited to dangerous or unhealthy jobs](image2) 

Furthermore, there are significant differences in how people perceive automation depending on their level of awareness. Those who are more familiar with the concept are more likely to believe it is realistic and to express excitement about it. [4, 9, 12] For example, among those who have heard a lot about this concept, 48% feel that robots may one day be able to accomplish many of the jobs now performed by people.  [12]

![Those who have heard a lot about machines replacing humans are more likely to find it realistic](image6)

On the other hand, just 4% of those who have never heard of it believe the same. [4] This emphasizes the significance of education and public discourse in influencing attitudes regarding automation. 

Overall, Americans have a mixed view of the possibility of robots performing many of the jobs now performed by people, and they anticipate both good and bad consequences. [6]

**In conclusion,  Americans generally view the concept of machines performing human jobs as realistic but are more worried than enthusiastic about it.**

Americans are divided on the issue of automation in the workforce. [1] While some believe businesses are justified in replacing human jobs with machines for better work at lower costs, a larger percentage of the population feels that there should be limits on this replacement.  [1]

![Public opinion is divided on whether businesses are justified in replacing humans with machines or if limits should be in place.](image8)

A majority of Americans support policies to limit the use of technology in specific situations or to incorporate humans more in their operation. [3] For example, 85% of Americans favor limiting machines to jobs that pose a danger to human health and safety. [4, 6] 

![The majority of Americans support limiting machines to performing dangerous and unhealthy jobs.](image1)

Public opinions are more divided on the topics of universal basic income and a national service program for displaced workers. [2, 9] While both policies received overall favorable responses, the majority of support came from Democrats with significantly less support from Republicans. [7, 12]

Although a large portion of Americans believe automation in the workforce is inevitable, a significant number of workers are not concerned that their jobs will be replaced by machines.  [10]  

![Most Americans believe that it will take 10 to less than 50 years for machines to be able to do many human jobs.](image3)
![Many Americans think it's unlikely that their jobs will be replaced by robots.](image4)

Overall, there is a general consensus that machines should primarily perform tasks that are dangerous to humans, but opinions are mixed regarding government intervention in the workforce.  [10]

Many Americans believe that a lack of encouragement for girls and minorities to pursue STEM from a young age is a major reason for the lack of diversity in the STEM workforce [1].  About half of STEM workers attribute this disparity to limited access to quality education [3]. 

![STEM workers are more likely to have a bachelor's degree than non-STEM workers.](image8)

![The percentage of women getting bachelor's degrees and working in STEM fields has not grown since 1990.](image4)

Black STEM workers are more likely to report experiencing discrimination in the workplace than other racial or ethnic groups, with 62% of Black STEM professionals stating they have faced discrimination because of their race or ethnicity [2]. Additionally, 72% of Black STEM workers believe that discrimination in recruiting, hiring, and promotions is a major reason for the underrepresentation of Blacks and Hispanics in these fields [4].

The most common reasons cited by the general public for the lack of representation of Blacks and Hispanics in STEM jobs include limited access to quality education (42%), lack of encouragement to pursue STEM subjects at an early age (40%), and a lack of Black and Hispanic role models in the field (27%) [8].

![The perceived major reasons why more women and minorities are not in STEM jobs.](image5)

Women are more likely to perceive discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions as a major reason for the lack of gender diversity in STEM [9].  39% of women believe that this is a significant factor [5].

In conclusion, major reasons cited by the Pew Research Center for underrepresentation in STEM jobs include lack of early encouragement, limited access to education, and discrimination.

U.S. adults generally have a lackluster view of K-12 public school education, [10], but their assessment of K-12 STEM education is only slightly better. [6]

Specifically, a quarter of U.S. adults believe K-12 STEM education in the U.S. is the best in the world or above average, while 43% consider it average and 30% believe it is below average. [10] 

However, STEM postgraduate degree holders hold a more critical view.  Only 13% of those with a STEM postgraduate degree consider K-12 STEM education as above average, while almost half (51%) believe the U.S. falls below average. [11] 

![STEM postgraduate degree holders rating of US STEM education from K-12 to graduate school ](image4) 

This suggests that people with specialized knowledge in STEM fields perceive K-12 STEM education as less effective than the general U.S. adult population.

In conclusion,  STEM postgraduate degree holders have a more negative view of the quality of K-12 STEM education in the U.S. compared to the general adult population.

The provided quotes explain how the document evaluates levels of confidence and likelihood. [11] Confidence is determined by the "type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency of evidence" and whether there is a general agreement among experts on the findings. [11] Likelihood is only applied if scientifically justified, and is used to describe the possibility of something occurring within a range of potential outcomes.  ![Likelihood Levels](image4)

Experts assess the available literature and decide the level of confidence by considering the quantity and quality of available data. [11] To determine the likelihood, they evaluate the level of agreement across different studies.  The specific process of evaluation is further detailed in the Traceable Account section for each chapter, Appendix 1: Technical Support Document, and Appendix 4: Documenting Uncertainty. [11]

The confidence level is expressed qualitatively, ranging from low to very high, while the likelihood level is based on probability. [9]
![Confidence Level](image8)

For example, a statement with very high confidence suggests strong evidence and a high degree of expert consensus, whereas a statement with low confidence might indicate inconclusive evidence or expert disagreement. [9] For likelihood, an event is considered "very likely" if there is greater than or equal to a 9 in 10 chance of it happening, while an event is "very unlikely" if there is less than or equal to a 1 in 10 chance. [3]

In conclusion, the levels of confidence and likelihood are evaluated based on the quality and quantity of evidence, expert consensus, and the probability of occurrence.

[7] Combining views of both political parties on ethics, a quarter of the public says “high ethical standards” describes neither the Republican Party nor the Democratic Party; 47% say it describes one party but not the other; and 17% say the description applies to both. 

![Perceptions of the ethics of the Republican and Democratic parties broken down by political affiliation, education level, and overall](image4)

[5] And independents are significantly more likely than partisans to say neither party has “high ethical standards.” About a third of independents (34%), including equal shares of Republican leaners and Democratic leaners (33% each) say neither party has high ethical standards. By comparison, only about two-in-ten Republicans (19%) or Democrats (18%) say this.

[11] Opinions about the traits of the two parties continue to be deeply divided along partisan lines. For example, overwhelming shares (more than 80%) of both Republicans and Republican-leaning independents and Democrats and Democratic leaners say their own party has good policy ideas, while less than a quarter say this describes the opposing party. Similarly, while only about two-in-ten Republicans or Democrats think their own party is “too extreme,” about three-quarters in each party think the other party can be described this way.  

![Perceptions of whether the Republican or Democratic party is "too extreme" broken down by political affiliation](image2)

Independents are more likely than Democrats or Republicans to view both parties as lacking high ethical standards, while partisans overwhelmingly favor their own party.  Additionally, partisans are more likely than independents to view the opposing party as "too extreme."

Public perception suggests minimal difference in ethical standards between the Democratic and Republican parties, with a slight majority viewing the Republican party as more extreme. [10] shows public views are similar when assessing policy ideas and ethical standards of both the Republican and Democratic parties. 
![Public View of Political Parties](image1)
However, perceptions vary based on education and political affiliation. Independents are more likely to perceive neither party as having high ethical standards, as seen in [5]. Specifically, about a third of independents (34%), believe that neither party upholds high ethical standards. [12] further supports this, showing that fewer individuals with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less (20%) share this sentiment.
![Perception of High Ethical Standards](image4)
Furthermore, [11] highlights that political affiliation heavily influences these perceptions. Over 80% of Republicans and Democrats believe their own party demonstrates good policy ideas, while less than 25% attribute this to the opposing party. Similarly, while only 20% of Republicans and Democrats consider their own party "too extreme," approximately 75% believe this describes the opposing party. 
This partisan divide is further emphasized when examining whether the phrase “high ethical standards” applies to both, one or neither of the parties. [6] states that a quarter of the public believe it applies to neither party, 47% believe it describes one but not the other, and 17% say it applies to both. 
In conclusion, while general public opinion sees little difference in ethical standards between the parties, individual perceptions are heavily skewed by education and political affiliation, with independents and those with higher education being more critical of both parties.

Americans' views of ethical standards in the GOP and Democratic party are similar, with 41% stating the GOP has high ethical standards and 42% thinking the same about the Democratic party [1]. 
![Public perception of whether the Republican or Democratic party has good policy ideas or high ethical standards](image4)
However, this perception changes among individuals with different education levels.  Nearly a third of college graduates believe neither party holds high ethical standards [5]. When considering if “high ethical standards” describes either party, 31% of those with at least a college degree state that it does not describe either party [10]. 
![Public perception by education level of whether "high ethical standards" describes either or both the Republican and Democratic parties](image5)
Furthermore, independents are significantly more likely to state that neither party maintains “high ethical standards.” 34% of independents, including 33% each of Republican and Democratic leaners, agree with that statement [9]. In contrast, only 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats share this viewpoint [9].  
When analyzing political affiliation, there are sizable differences in early midterm vote preference based on education level. Individuals with a postgraduate degree support the Democratic candidate over the Republican candidate by a nearly two-to-one margin (62% to 30%) [8]. Similarly, those with a four-year college degree favor the Democrat, 53% to 40% [8]. However, preferences are more divided among voters who do not have a college degree [8].
![Percentage of voters who would vote for the Democratic or Republican candidate in the 2018 midterms, broken down by demographics](image3)
In conclusion, perceptions of higher ethical standards are lower among people with higher education and those not affiliated with a specific political party, and higher education is correlated with more support for Democratic candidates.

Public approval of the government's counter-terrorism efforts has generally trended downwards since the beginning of the Bush administration, with a particularly steep drop following the beginning of the Obama administration.
![Republican approval of the government's counter-terrorism efforts dropped sharply at the start of the Obama administration.](image4)

More specifically, at the start of 2015, a majority of Americans felt that the government was doing well in its efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism [2].  However, this perception has shifted, and in recent years, more Americans believe that the government has not gone far enough in its counter-terrorism efforts, rather than being too restrictive of civil liberties. This shift is especially pronounced among Republicans [1, 7]. Older Americans are also more likely to view the government's counter-terrorism efforts negatively compared to younger adults [6]. 

![More Americans believe the government's anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough, a trend that has intensified since 2013.](image1)

These differing opinions likely stem from a variety of factors, including political affiliation, age, and perceptions of civil liberties. For example, Republicans are much more likely to believe that the government has not gone far enough in its anti-terrorism policies, even compared to conservative Democrats [8]. 

![A greater percentage of Republicans than Democrats or Independents believe that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough.](image2)

Overall, public perceptions of the government’s efforts to combat terrorism have become more negative in recent years, with Republicans and older Americans expressing greater disapproval. This suggests that public concern over terrorism remains significant, and that there is no clear consensus on the best way to balance security measures with the protection of civil liberties.

Older Americans are more likely to view government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat negatively than younger Americans. For example, 57% of those 50 and older believe the government is not doing well in this area, compared to 46% of those aged 18-29. [4]

Younger adults are more concerned about U.S. policies restricting civil liberties, while older age groups prioritize security over civil liberties. [9] Looking at changes over time, both Democrats and Republicans have become more critical of the government's efforts to combat terrorism. [3] 

![Approval of the way Obama is handling terrorism is lowest among republicans and higher among democrats.](image5)

![Concerns about government anti-terror policies not going far enough to protect the country have increased while concerns about restricting civil liberties have decreased over time.](image6)

**Answer:** Older Americans and Republicans tend to be more critical of government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat, while younger Americans and Democrats are more likely to view these efforts favorably. Republicans are more critical of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic than Democrats, and this criticism has become more pronounced over time.

A Pew Research Center survey [2] conducted in June-July 2020 provides insights into how Americans perceive China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and its implications for U.S.-China relations.

The survey reveals a strong partisan divide in how Americans view China. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to hold negative views of China and criticize its handling of the coronavirus outbreak [2]. This difference is evident in the percentage of respondents who believe that the U.S. should prioritize holding China responsible for its role in the pandemic, even if it means jeopardizing economic ties. A significant majority of Republicans (71%) support this approach, while only 37% of Democrats share this stance [3]. 

![Republicans are more critical than Democrats regarding China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak]()(image2)

Furthermore, the survey highlights that those who perceive China's handling of the outbreak negatively tend to hold unfavorable views of the country [12]. This suggests a correlation between perceptions of China's pandemic response and overall opinions about the nation.

Analyzing the trends across different political affiliations reveals a consistent pattern:

![Republican views on China's role in the coronavirus outbreak have grown more negative since 2011]()(image3)

Republicans consistently show more critical stances towards China compared to Democrats. This difference is particularly pronounced in their views on China's early management of the pandemic and their preference for a tougher stance in U.S.-China relations [9].

The data indicates a clear and widening gap between Republicans and Democrats in their views on China and its role in the coronavirus outbreak.

**In conclusion, Republicans are more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and favor a tougher approach in US-China relations compared to Democrats.**

Americans overwhelmingly believe that China did a bad job handling the coronavirus outbreak. [8] 
![64% of Americans think China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak](image1)  
Furthermore, a strong majority of Americans (78%) attribute a significant amount of blame to the Chinese government's initial handling of the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan for its global spread. [8] ![78% of Americans place a great deal or fair amount of the blame for the global spread of the coronavirus on the Chinese government](image5) This sentiment has led to a souring of views on U.S.-China relations, with a significant number of Americans viewing economic ties between the two countries as poor and a growing number considering China an enemy. [12] This negative perception is reflected in the finding that half of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role in the pandemic, even if it jeopardizes economic relations. [6]

However, the survey also reveals a nuanced perspective on the issue of blame and economic ties. Despite the desire to hold China accountable for its handling of the pandemic, Americans slightly favor pursuing a strong economic relationship with China (51%) over taking a tough stance (46%). [3] This suggests a recognition of the complex economic interdependence between the two nations. Interestingly, those who perceive China's economic dominance are less inclined to support aggressive economic measures against China, instead prioritizing a strong bilateral economic relationship. [2] This implies that perceptions of economic power dynamics might moderate opinions on how to approach the U.S.-China relationship in light of the pandemic.

Examining the partisan divide adds another layer to understanding the evolution of American opinions. Both Republicans and Democrats express negative views of China and criticize its handling of the coronavirus. However, this criticism is significantly more pronounced among Republicans. [4] This partisan gap is evident in various aspects, with Republicans exhibiting a higher likelihood of holding a very unfavorable view of China, criticizing the Chinese government's response to the pandemic, and advocating for a more assertive policy approach toward China. [4] This partisan difference is illustrated in Image 2, which shows consistently higher percentages of Republicans (and those who lean Republican) across various negative perceptions and policy preferences towards China compared to their Democratic counterparts. ![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to view China as an enemy and to blame China for COVID-19.](image2) Notably, the largest differences between Republicans and Democrats are observed in their views on blaming China for the pandemic, holding China responsible even if it impacts economic relations, and considering China an enemy.

In conclusion, American perceptions of China's handling of COVID-19 are largely negative and have contributed to a worsening view of U.S.-China relations, particularly among Republicans, yet there remains a desire for a strong economic relationship.

However, roughly half of Germans name China   $(53\%)$   as the leading economic power  compared with  $24\%$   who name the U.S. Relatively few in both countries see Japan or the countries  of the European Union as the leading economic power, although  $14\%$   in Germany name the EU,  about twice as many as in the U.S.  

![Germans are more likely to see China as the world's leading economic power, while Americans are more likely to believe it is the U.S.](image8)

[6] Americans and Germans also hold different  opinions on countries and international  organizations. On balance, Germans tend to  view these nations and organizations more  positively than Americans. This divide is  starkest when it comes to views of the EU.  While roughly seven-in-ten Germans favor the  union, only about half of Americans agree. A  similarly wide gap exists between German and  American perceptions of Russia, though  favorable opinions of Russia are less  widespread in both countries than positive  views of the UN and EU. There is greater  consensus on the UN and NATO, though  notably, Germans tend to think more highly of  these organizations than Americans. About  one-in-five Americans express no opinion of  either the EU or NATO.  

![Germans view the EU and China more favorably than Americans](image2)

Germans are more likely to view China as the world's leading economic power and hold more favorable opinions of the EU and China than Americans.

Americans and Germans generally express divergent viewpoints regarding international organizations and leading economic powers. For instance, a considerably higher percentage of Germans hold favorable opinions of the European Union (EU) compared to Americans, with 69% of Germans expressing support for the EU in contrast to 51% of Americans. [10]

![Germans generally view the EU more favorably than Americans](image5)

This contrast might stem from the EU's direct impact on Germany's economic and political landscape, fostering a sense of shared interests and interconnectedness. Further emphasizing this divide, a mere 6% of Americans perceive the EU as the leading economic power, whereas 14% of Germans hold this view. [7]

Furthermore, while a majority in both countries perceive the US as the top economic power,  a larger proportion of Americans (50%) share this view compared to their German counterparts (24%). Conversely, Germans are more inclined (53%) to recognize China as the leading economic power compared to Americans (32%). [7]  This difference in perception is illustrated below:

![More Americans view the US as the top economic power, while Germans favor China.](image1)

Ideological leanings appear to significantly influence these perceptions, particularly among Americans.  Conservative Americans tend to view Russia more favorably than liberals, while the latter group displays a stronger preference for the UN and EU. [11] 

![The gap between liberal and conservative views towards international organizations is wider in the US than in Germany.](image6)

The fact that such ideological divides are less pronounced among Germans suggests a greater degree of consensus within German society regarding international relations, possibly due to shared historical experiences and a more homogenous political culture.

In conclusion, differing levels of exposure to and dependence on these entities likely contribute to the disparity in views. Additionally, the more pronounced ideological divide among Americans, as opposed to Germans, suggests a greater influence of domestic political factors on foreign policy perceptions in the US.

Americans are more likely than Germans to believe that the use of military force is sometimes necessary (78% vs 47%). [9] 
![US citizens are more likely to agree to the necessity of military force than German citizens](image8)
In both the US and Germany, younger people view the US-Germany relationship more positively than older people. [11]
![Younger Americans and Germans view their countries' relationship more positively](image3)
While there is no clear consensus in either country on whether European allies should bolster their defense spending, a greater number of Germans favor either increasing or maintaining current spending levels compared to Americans. [8]  Fewer Americans see a need for increased European defense spending, with 50% believing it should stay the same. [3] This marks a notable shift from 2017, when 45% of Americans thought European allies should increase defense spending. [3]  In Germany, the public is split on increasing (40%) or maintaining (41%) defense spending. [7] 
![Opinions on whether European allies should increase defense spending](image6)
Opinions in the US on the necessity of European allies increasing defense spending are divided by political affiliation. Republicans are more likely to be in favor, although support has dropped 14% between 2017 and 2019. [2]
![Republican support for increased defense spending among European allies is declining](image1)
The US and Germany have very different views on whether to use military force to defend a NATO ally against Russia. [10]
![Differing opinions on defending a NATO Ally in the US and Germany](image5)
While the US public is more in favor of military force overall, a large majority consider the US-Germany relationship to be good.  [5, 4] 
![The majority of Americans see the US-Germany relationship as "Good"](image2)
Germans feel less positively about the relationship, but younger Germans have a more favorable view than older generations. [4]
![The majority of Americans see the US-Germany relationship as "Good"](image2)
The US public places a higher level of importance on the US-Germany relationship than Germans do. [4]
![US citizens find their relationship with Germany more important than German citizens do](image4)
**In conclusion, Americans are more likely than Germans to support military force; younger generations in both countries view the US-Germany relationship more positively, and Americans place a higher value on the relationship overall.**

Americans are more likely to support military intervention and increased defense spending than Germans.  [3, 6] 78% of Americans agree that it is sometimes necessary to use military force to maintain order in the world, compared to only 47% of Germans. ![Shows Americans are more likely to agree to using military force than Germans.](image8) For example, on the issue of defending a NATO ally in the event of a Russian attack, 60% of Americans believe in upholding Article 5 obligations, while 60% of Germans disagree. [11] ![Shows opposing opinions from Americans and Germans on the use of force to defend a NATO ally.](image3) This difference in opinion is also reflected in views on defense spending. While half of Americans believe European allies should maintain their current defense spending, there is a division in Germany, with 40% supporting an increase and 41% preferring to maintain the status quo. [12] ![Shows public opinion in Germany and the U.S. on increasing European allies' spending on defense.](image5)  Germans are less convinced about the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany for their own country's security, with 45% disagreeing with their presence. [5] In contrast, Americans strongly believe in the significance of these bases for U.S. security interests (85%). [8]  The age demographics play a role as well. While in the U.S., the younger generation (18-29) is less likely to see U.S. military bases in Germany as important (38% compared to 61% of those 65 and older), there is no such generational divide in Germany. [4] ![Shows age demographics of Americans who find U.S. military bases important, with older Americans more likely to agree.](image4) Interestingly, in the U.S., both Republicans and Democrats have shown a decline in support for increased European defense budgets from 2017 to 2019. [4]  ![This chart illustrates how opinions on using military force vary by age in the U.S. and Germany.](image1) 

In conclusion, Americans are more supportive of military intervention and see U.S. military bases in Germany as crucial for their security, while Germans are more divided on these issues and show less enthusiasm for increased defense spending.

Americans and Germans have differing opinions on defense spending, both in terms of their overall views and how these opinions break down along party lines.  

When it comes to defense spending by European allies, Americans are less likely to see a need for increased spending compared to previous years, with half now believing it should stay the same [3]. This is illustrated by the declining percentage of Americans who support increased defense spending by European allies between 2017 and 2019.

![Percentage of Americans supporting increased defense spending in Europe declined between 2017 and 2019](image1) 

Within the US, this shift is primarily driven by Republicans, whose support for increased European defense spending decreased by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019.  Despite this decrease, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are still more likely to favor increased defense spending in Europe than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [9].

![Percentage of Democrats and Republicans supporting increased defense spending in Europe over time](image2) 

In Germany, however, public opinion is divided on whether to increase defense spending or maintain current levels [8]. This represents a change from 2017, when roughly half of Germans were content with their country’s level of defense spending.

Regarding partisan differences within Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU party generally favor increased defense spending, while Green party supporters express skepticism [11]. 

![Percent of individuals in different German political parties that believe Germany should increase defense spending](image6)

Overall, American opinions on the need for increased European defense spending have softened in recent years, particularly among Republicans. In contrast, Germans are divided on increasing their own country’s defense spending, with partisan differences also apparent in their views.

In 2017, a larger share of Americans believed that European allies should increase their spending on national defense. However, this sentiment decreased from 2017 to 2019, with half of Americans believing that spending levels should remain the same by 2019 [7]. 

![Evolution of American views on European allies' defense spending from 2017 to 2019](image4)

The decline in support for increased defense spending in Europe is evident across both parties in the US. Although Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents to support increased defense spending by European allies, their support has decreased by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [12]. 

![Evolution of US political parties' views on European allies' defense spending from 2017 to 2019](image3)

In Germany, opinions are divided regarding whether to increase or maintain current levels of spending on national defense. However, this represents a change from 2017, when approximately half of Germans were content with their country’s defense spending, while about a third felt it should be increased [3].

Looking at partisan differences within Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of defense spending increases [1]. 

![Percentage of those who voted for each party in the 2017 Bundestag elections who support increased defense spending in Germany](image8)

Overall, between 2017 and 2019, support for increased defense spending by European allies declined in the US across both parties, while in Germany, the public is increasingly divided on this issue, with partisan differences evident.

In the U.S., Republicans are more likely to favor increased defense spending in Europe than Democrats [2]. However, the percentage of Republicans who believe European allies should increase defense spending has decreased from 2017 to 2019 [2]. 

![Republican support for increased European defense spending decreased from 2017 to 2019](image7)

In Germany, the CDU/CSU supporters are more likely to favor increased defense spending compared to the Greens and SPD [9]. 

![51% of CDU/CSU supporters are in favor of increasing defense spending, compared to 41% of SPD supporters and 28% of Greens supporters](image4)

Overall, while Republicans in the U.S. are more likely to favor increased defense spending by European allies, their support has decreased in recent years. In Germany, the CDU/CSU are the most supportive of increased defense spending.

In Germany, age significantly influences the perception of U.S. military bases' importance. Specifically, younger Germans (18-29) are less likely to see these bases as important for national security compared to their older counterparts (65+). ![The importance of U.S military bases for German national security varies by age group](image8) 

Conversely, political affiliations in the U.S. play a key role in shaping opinions on foreign policy partners. While both Republicans and Democrats prioritize the UK, Republicans lean towards Israel, while Democrats favor Canada and Mexico. Interestingly, Germany consistently ranks fifth for both parties. ![The percentage of Republicans/Lean Republicans and Democrats/Lean Democrats who say each country is the most or second most important foreign policy partner for the U.S](image1) 

Therefore, age differences in Germany mainly affect opinions on the importance of U.S. military bases, while in the U.S., political affiliations heavily influence preferred foreign policy partners.

Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say that the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can, as opposed to saying that the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems.  [7] 
![Describes people's views on if the U.S. does too much, too little, or the right amount in world affairs.](image1)Those with higher levels of education are more supportive of helping other nations deal with their problems. [6]  For example, 60% of those with postgraduate degrees say the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems while only 29% of those with a high school education or less agree. [5, 6] 
![Describes how people feel about the amount the U.S. does in world affairs.](image2)
![Shows the percentage of people, broken down by demographics, who believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak.](image4)
![Shows the percentage of Americans, broken down by demographics, who believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems.](image5)
When it comes to how the U.S. has dealt with the coronavirus outbreak, there is a significant partisan divide, with Democrats more likely to be critical of the U.S.’s response than Republicans.  [11] 
![Shows the percentage of people, broken down by demographics, who believe China has done a good or excellent job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak.](image3)
![Shows percentage of Republicans and Democrats who rate each country as having done a good job responding to the outbreak.](image8)


**Answer:** Republicans are more likely to believe that the U.S. should focus on its own issues rather than helping other countries, while Democrats are more likely to support global engagement; those with higher levels of education are also more likely to support helping other countries.

Republicans are much more likely than Democrats to view the U.S. response to the COVID-19 outbreak favorably, with 71% of Republicans and only 27% of Democrats believing the U.S. did a good or excellent job [6, 7].  ![Republican leaning Americans are much more likely to say the U.S. has done a good or excellent job in handling COVID-19 than Democrat leaning Americans.](image4) Conversely, on the topic of China's handling of the outbreak, there is a much smaller difference in opinion between Democrats and Republicans [9]. However, when it comes to whether the U.S. can learn from other countries in handling the outbreak, Republicans who believe that there are lessons to be learned are more likely to view other countries' handling of the pandemic favorably, a trend that holds true for Democrats as well [8]. ![Americans who believe that the U.S. can learn from other countries on how to slow the spread of Coronavirus are more likely to say that those countries are dealing with the pandemic effectively](image5)  Education level does not have a significant effect on opinions of China's handling of the pandemic [1].  However, Americans with higher levels of education are more critical of how the U.S. dealt with COVID-19, with nearly two-thirds of Americans with postgraduate degrees saying the U.S. did a poor job [10]. 

**Conclusion:** Republicans are more likely than Democrats to view the U.S. response to COVID-19 favorably and education level does not impact views on China's handling of the pandemic but higher education levels correlate to less favorable views of the U.S. response.

[10] Wide partisan gap on how U.S. has dealt  with coronavirus; smaller differences in  views of other countries’ responses   

[9] There are significant partisan differences on  this question. While half or more of people on  both sides of the aisle say China has not done a  good job dealing with the outbreak,  Republicans are much more likely to hold this  view than Democrats. Conservative  Republicans are particularly likely to say China  has not handled the crisis well: Eight-in-ten  hold this view.  

![Republicans are more likely to view the U.S. response favorably while Democrats are more critical.](image7)

![Republicans, especially conservative Republicans, are far more likely to view China's response negatively.](image8)

Political affiliations heavily influence perceptions of how the U.S. and China handled COVID-19: Republicans view the U.S. response more favorably, while Democrats are more critical; Republicans, particularly conservatives, view China's response far more negatively.

[5] There is a significant partisan divide in how much the U.S. can learn from other countries regarding pandemic response.  While  60%  of Democrats and  Democratic-leaning  independents say the U.S. can  learn a great deal, just  28%   of  Republicans and Republican  leaners share that view.  

[2] This partisan divide is  especially pronounced on views  about the WHO;  86%   of liberal  Democrats say they trust  information from the WHO at  least a fair amount, compared  with   27%   of conservative  Republicans. Similar, though  somewhat smaller, divisions  also exist in trust in  information from the EU and  the Chinese government.  

![Trust level of information from EU, WHO and Chinese government across political spectrum](image3)

![The level of trust in information from the EU, WHO and the Chinese Government by education level](image1)

Democrats are more likely to believe the U.S. can learn from other countries' experiences during the pandemic, and they also have higher trust levels in organizations like the WHO and EU. In contrast, Republicans are less likely to see value in learning from other nations and exhibit lower trust levels in these international organizations.

Republicans are more likely than Democrats to believe that the U.S. will emerge from the coronavirus outbreak with more influence. Conversely, Democrats are more likely to believe that U.S. influence will decline. [1]  In contrast, a majority of Americans believe that China will emerge from the crisis with less influence in world affairs. [9]  When considering the EU, majorities in both parties believe its influence will remain unchanged. [3]

![Breakdown of Republicans and Democrats who think the U.S. will have more, less, or the same influence after the outbreak](image1)

![Breakdown of Republicans and Democrats who think the EU will have more, less, or the same influence after the outbreak](image8)

Education level is also tied to these views. Americans with higher levels of education are more likely to believe that the U.S.'s global influence will decrease as a result of the pandemic. [10] 

![Breakdown by education level of Americans who think the U.S. will have more, less, or the same influence after the outbreak](image1)

In conclusion, Republicans are more optimistic than Democrats about the future global influence of the U.S., while both parties believe the EU's influence will remain unchanged and China's will decline. Americans with higher levels of education are more likely to believe that U.S. global influence will decline.

[1] These partisan and age divides are similar to  other  attitudes about China. Older Americans  and Republicans are also especially likely to say  they have a negative opinion of China.

![This chart displays the percentage of people who believe the U.S., E.U., or China will have more, less, or about the same global influence after the coronavirus outbreak](image7)

Republicans and older Americans are more likely to believe that China will have less influence in the world after the Coronavirus outbreak than Democrats and younger Americans. Fewer people believe that the U.S. will have less influence after the outbreak than believe that about China.

Americans largely view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively. [9] Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe that China has not done a good job dealing with the outbreak.  [7] There is a lack of trust in information about the coronavirus coming from the Chinese government. 

![Shows American opinion is split on whether China will have more, less, or about the same global influence after the coronavirus outbreak.](image7) 

While opinion is split on whether China's global influence will increase, decrease, or stay the same as a result of the outbreak, there are significant partisan differences in these perceptions. This partisan difference is evident in how Americans view China's future global influence. [5] For example, around 60% of Republicans believe that China's influence will decline because of the coronavirus outbreak, while only 40% of Democrats share the same view. 

![Shows level of trust in information about the coronavirus from the Chinese government.](image6)

![Shows the percentage of Americans, broken down by demographics, who believe that the U.S. should focus on its own problems and let other countries deal with theirs.](image1) 

The partisan divide extends to other issues related to the pandemic and foreign affairs. [1] Notably, when it comes to America's role in international affairs, 60% of Democrats think the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, while only 24% of Republicans agree. 

In conclusion,  a majority of Americans view China's handling of the coronavirus negatively, and there are significant partisan differences in how Americans perceive China's future global influence.

Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say that the U.S. does too much to solve world problems. [4]

[4]  However, there are differences in opinion based on political ideology, with liberal Democrats being more likely to support helping other countries. [12]

Republicans are more likely to believe that the U.S. is doing too much to solve world problems, with 62% of Republicans holding this view compared to only 26% of Democrats [11]. Conversely, Democrats are more likely to believe that the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, with 64% of liberal Democrats supporting this view compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [2].
